newsitem.title: ITALY: Italian police arrest former ENI executive.
newsitem.headline: Italian police arrest former ENI executive.

text.p: The former vice president of energy group ENI, Alberto Grotti, was arrested on Thursday after a court upheld a jail sentence against him on graft charges, police said.
The charges had also involved former prime minister Bettino Craxi and eight other defendants.
Grotti, sentenced to just over four years in jail for a scandal over bribes paid by insurance firm SAI to win contracts from ENI, was arrested in Rome.
Italy's highest court on Tuesday confirmed Grotti's conviction as well as sentences against Craxi, financier Sergio Cusani and seven others.
Police are still searching for convicted former ENI executive Antonio Sernia and insurer Aldo Molino.

Cusani, who helped expose the rampant graft in Italy's political old guard, turned himself in to prison authorities on Wednesday to begin serving a four-year sentence for his role in the ENI-SAI saga.

Craxi, who lives in self-imposed exile in Tunisia, was sentenced to 5-1/2-years for illegal party financing. Premier from 1983 to 1987, the former Socialist has more than 25 years of jail sentences accumulated against him from other trials.
Italy's vast graft scandals broke in February 1992 when the manager of a Milan old people's home confessed to taking bribes on behalf of Craxi's Socialist party.
